message.content: Is there any built in obsidian MCP server?

content.text: I'll check what MCP servers are available to you.

No MCP servers are currently configured. There is no built-in Obsidian MCP server available in your environment.

However, if you're interested in using an Obsidian MCP server, you would need to:
1. Find or develop an MCP server that supports Obsidian
2. Configure it in your Claude Code settings

If you're aware of an Obsidian MCP server that exists, I can help you set it up. Alternatively, if you're looking to work with Obsidian files directly, I can help you read and manipulate them using the standard file tools (Read, Edit, Write).

It provides a comprehensive suite of tools for reading, writing, searching, and managing notes, tags, and frontmatter, acting as a bridge to the Obsidian Local REST API plugin.","url":"https://github.com/cyanheads/obsidian-mcp-server"},{"title":"Writing 2,000 words in 90 minutes with Obsidian + MCP + Claude.","url":"https://www.haihai.ai/obsidian-mcp/"},{"title":"Automate Note Generation in Obsidian with Claude Desktop and MCP Servers - Share & showcase - Obsidian Forum","url":"https://forum.obsidian.md/t/automate-note-generation-in-obsidian-with-claude-desktop-and-mcp-servers/99542"},{"title":"How I Built a Local MCP Server to Connect Obsidian with AI | by Hyunjong Lee | Level Up Coding","url":"https://levelup.gitconnected.com/how-i-built-a-local-mcp-server-to-connect-obsidian-with-ai-55121295a985"},{"title":"How to Use the Obsidian MCP Server","url":"https://apidog.com/blog/obsidian-mcp-server/"},{"title":"Obsidian MCP Server","url":"https://glama.ai/mcp/servers/@StevenStavrakis/obsidian-mcp"},{"title":"MCP server that can read rendered Dataview queries - Help - Obsidian Forum","url":"https://forum.obsidian.md/t/mcp-server-that-can-read-rendered-dataview-queries/101663"}]

## Search Results: Obsidian MCP Server

Based on the search results, here's what you need to know about Obsidian MCP servers:

### What It Is

The Obsidian MCP Server is a specialized implementation of Anthropic's Model Context Protocol (MCP) designed specifically to interact with Obsidian vaults.(no content)MCP is an open-source protocol developed by Anthropic that enables AI systems like Claude to securely connect with various data sources.

### Key Capabilities

The Model Context Protocol (MCP) server for Obsidian enables AI tools to interact with your Obsidian vaults, providing capabilities for reading, creating, editing, and managing notes and tags.(no content)It enables LLMs and AI agents to read, write, search, and manage your notes and files through the Obsidian Local REST API plugin.(no content)The server offers content access (read and search notes), content creation (create new notes and directories), content management (edit existing notes, move files, and delete content), tag organization, and search capabilities across vault contents.

### Popular Implementations

There are several MCP server implementations for Obsidian available on GitHub:
- One server interacts with Obsidian via the Local REST API community plugin.
- Another knowledge-management MCP server enables AI agents and development tools to interact with an Obsidian vault, providing a comprehensive suite of tools for reading, writing, searching, and managing notes, tags, and frontmatter.

### Getting Started

The desktop version of Claude can act as an MCP client, which means that it can interact with MCP servers.(no content)Before using it, you should note that Obsidian MCP Server requires careful handling as it has both read and write access to your vault, and you should always back up your Obsidian vault before using this tool.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

## Search Results: Obsidian MCP Server

Based on the search results, here's what you need to know about Obsidian MCP servers:

### What It Is

The Obsidian MCP Server is a specialized implementation of Anthropic's Model Context Protocol (MCP) designed specifically to interact with Obsidian vaults.(no content)MCP is an open-source protocol developed by Anthropic that enables AI systems like Claude to securely connect with various data sources.

### Key Capabilities

The Model Context Protocol (MCP) server for Obsidian enables AI tools to interact with your Obsidian vaults, providing capabilities for reading, creating, editing, and managing notes and tags.(no content)It enables LLMs and AI agents to read, write, search, and manage your notes and files through the Obsidian Local REST API plugin.(no content)The server offers content access (read and search notes), content creation (create new notes and directories), content management (edit existing notes, move files, and delete content), tag organization, and search capabilities across vault contents.

### Popular Implementations

There are several MCP server implementations for Obsidian available on GitHub:
- One server interacts with Obsidian via the Local REST API community plugin.
- Another knowledge-management MCP server enables AI agents and development tools to interact with an Obsidian vault, providing a comprehensive suite of tools for reading, writing, searching, and managing notes, tags, and frontmatter.

### Getting Started

The desktop version of Claude can act as an MCP client, which means that it can interact with MCP servers.(no content)Before using it, you should note that Obsidian MCP Server requires careful handling as it has both read and write access to your vault, and you should always back up your Obsidian vault before using this tool.

content.text:
Yes, there are several Obsidian MCP servers available! Here are the main ones:

**Popular Implementations:**
1. [mcp-obsidian](https://github.com/MarkusPfundstein/mcp-obsidian) - Interacts with Obsidian via the Obsidian REST API community plugin
2. [obsidian-mcp-server](https://github.com/cyanheads/obsidian-mcp-server) - A knowledge-management MCP server that enables reading, writing, searching, and managing notes, tags, and frontmatter
3. [Obsidian MCP on Glama](https://glama.ai/mcp/servers/@StevenStavrakis/obsidian-mcp) - Another available server implementation

**Key Features:**
- Read and write notes in your Obsidian vault
- Search across vault contents
- Manage tags and frontmatter
- Create new notes and directories
- Edit and delete existing content

**Important:** You'll need to have the **Obsidian Local REST API community plugin** installed in your vault before using any of these servers. Also, always backup your vault before connecting to avoid accidental data loss.

To set one up, you'd configure it as an MCP server in your Claude Code settings.

Sources:
- [GitHub - MarkusPfundstein/mcp-obsidian](https://github.com/MarkusPfundstein/mcp-obsidian)
- [GitHub - cyanheads/obsidian-mcp-server](https://github.com/cyanheads/obsidian-mcp-server)
- [Getting Started with Obsidian MCP Server](https://medium.com/towards-agi/getting-started-with-obsidian-mcp-server-a-comprehensive-guide-6f44ba3fb279)

Repository files navigation
README
MIT license
MCP server for Obsidian
MCP server to interact with Obsidian via the Local REST API community plugin.

server for Obsidian MCP server

Components
Tools
The server implements multiple tools to interact with Obsidian:

list_files_in_vault: Lists all files and directories in the root directory of your Obsidian vault
list_files_in_dir: Lists all files and directories in a specific Obsidian directory
get_file_contents: Return the content of a single file in your vault.
search: Search for documents matching a specified text query across all files in the vault
patch_content: Insert content into an existing note relative to a heading, block reference, or frontmatter field.
append_content: Append content to a new or existing file in the vault.
delete_file: Delete a file or directory from your vault.
Example prompts
Its good to first instruct Claude to use Obsidian. Then it will always call the tool.

The use prompts like this:

Get the contents of the last architecture call note and summarize them
Search for all files where Azure CosmosDb is mentioned and quickly explain to me the context in which it is mentioned
Summarize the last meeting notes and put them into a new note 'summary meeting.md'. Add an introduction so that I can send it via email.
Configuration
Obsidian REST API Key
There are two ways to configure the environment with the Obsidian REST API Key.

Add to server config (preferred)
{
  "mcp-obsidian": {
    "command": "uvx",
    "args": [
      "mcp-obsidian"
    ],
    "env": {
      "OBSIDIAN_API_KEY": "<your_api_key_here>",
      "OBSIDIAN_HOST": "<your_obsidian_host>",
      "OBSIDIAN_PORT": "<your_obsidian_port>"
    }
  }
}
Sometimes Claude has issues detecting the location of uv / uvx. You can use which uvx to find and paste the full path in above config in such cases.

Create a .env file in the working directory with the following required variables:
OBSIDIAN_API_KEY=your_api_key_here
OBSIDIAN_HOST=your_obsidian_host
OBSIDIAN_PORT=your_obsidian_port
Note:

You can find the API key in the Obsidian plugin config
Default port is 27124 if not specified
Default host is 127.0.0.1 if not specified
Quickstart
Install
Obsidian REST API
You need the Obsidian REST API community plugin running: https://github.com/coddingtonbear/obsidian-local-rest-api

Install and enable it in the settings and copy the api key.

Claude Desktop
On MacOS: ~/Library/Application\ Support/Claude/claude_desktop_config.json

On Windows: %APPDATA%/Claude/claude_desktop_config.json

Development/Unpublished Servers Configuration
Published Servers Configuration
Development
Building
To prepare the package for distribution:

Sync dependencies and update lockfile:
uv sync
Debugging
Since MCP servers run over stdio, debugging can be challenging. For the best debugging experience, we strongly recommend using the MCP Inspector.

You can launch the MCP Inspector via npm with this command:

npx @modelcontextprotocol/inspector uv --directory /path/to/mcp-obsidian run mcp-obsidian
Upon launching, the Inspector will display a URL that you can access in your browser to begin debugging.

You can also watch the server logs with this command:

tail -n 20 -f ~/Library/Logs/Claude/mcp-server-mcp-obsidian.log
About
MCP server that interacts with Obsidian via the Obsidian rest API community plugin

content.text:
I'll help you set up the mcp-obsidian server. Let me break down the steps:

## Setup Steps

1. **Install the Obsidian REST API Plugin**
   - In Obsidian, go to Settings → Community plugins → Browse
   - Search for "Local REST API" by coddingtonbear
   - Install and enable it
   - Copy your API key from the plugin settings

2. **Configure Claude Desktop**
   
   Find your Claude config file:
   - **MacOS**: `~/Library/Application\ Support/Claude/claude_desktop_config.json`
   - **Windows**: `%APPDATA%/Claude/claude_desktop_config.json`

   Add this to your config:
   ```json
   {
     "mcp-obsidian": {
       "command": "uvx",
       "args": ["mcp-obsidian"],
       "env": {
         "OBSIDIAN_API_KEY": "<your_api_key_from_plugin>",
         "OBSIDIAN_HOST": "127.0.0.1",
         "OBSIDIAN_PORT": "27124"
       }
     }
   }
   ```

3. **Available Tools**
   Once configured, you'll have access to:
   - `list_files_in_vault` - List all files in your vault
   - `list_files_in_dir` - List files in a specific directory
   - `get_file_contents` - Read file contents
   - `search` - Search across your vault
   - `patch_content` - Insert content relative to headings/references
   - `append_content` - Append to files
   - `delete_file` - Delete files or directories

4. **Usage Tips**
   - Start by instructing Claude to use Obsidian
   - Example: "Get the contents of the last architecture call note and summarize them"
   - The MCP Inspector can help with debugging: `npx @modelcontextprotocol/inspector uv --directory /path/to/mcp-obsidian run mcp-obsidian`

That's it! After restarting Claude Desktop, the Obsidian MCP server will be available.
